titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to the Frank R. Gould Papers
1930-1993
MS 3228
titlestmt.author: Paul-Louis Biondi (June 2023)

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-01-30 11:27:01 -0500.
profiledesc.langusage: Finding aid is written in English

did.abstract: The Frank R. Gould papers comprise letters, scripts, and ephemera related to Frank Gould's life and career as a writer in New York City for radio dramas, Broadway, magazines, and newspapers. The bulk of this collection focuses on the 1940s and his writing, including scripts he wrote for Inner Sanctum Mystery, a radio program that aired from 1941 to 1952. In addition, there is a scrapbook made by Gould and a digital copy of his autobiography, God Shed His Grace on Me, written shortly before his death in 1993.
did.physloc: This collection may be stored offsite. For information on arranging to consult it, please visit www.nyhistory.org/library/visit.
did.langmaterial: This collection is in English. Two documents are in Turkish.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized by topic and genre. Folders are arranged chronologically when possible.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Frank R. Gould (born Rayful Goldberg), a Jewish New Yorker born in 1906, was a prolific playwright and actor throughout his life. This collection, the bulk of which dates from the 1940s, features many of the scripts he wrote for Broadway shows and radio dramas. It also documents his time in the U.S. Office of War Information Features Division as a writer in the 1940s. Born in the Russian partition of Poland, Gould immigrated to the United States through Ellis Island in the 1920s. He went to Columbia University for college and graduated from the School of Journalism. Soon after, he spent time on the staff of the Brooklyn Eagle, a daily newspaper published from 1841 to 1955, and the Brooklyn Times-Union, itself bought by Brooklyn Eagle in 1937, before focusing on his playwriting and acting. Around this time, he also met and married Ruth Yagendorf Gould on May 30, 1936.

Working freelance for Himan Brown, an American producer of over 30,000 radio programs, Gould wrote scripts for radio programs such as March of Time, one of the first dramatized radio newsreels -- staged and performed like a drama while sharing news content. Gould also wrote for The Columbia Workshop, a program dedicated to entertaining and experimenting with the genre of radio drama. In 1941, he created the program City Desk, a radio drama that followed two detectives as they uncovered murder mysteries, exposed corrupt politics, and pursued romance in the large metropolis. Although uncredited, Gould also originated and wrote the first, seventh, and tenth episodes of Inner Sanctum Mystery, a popular radio program mixing horror and humor that aired from 1941 to 1952 (the scripts can be found in the collection). At the same time, Gould performed on Broadway in such productions as Having Wonderful Time (1937-1938), Escape This Night (1938), and Cafe Crown (1942) and wrote plays such as The Scene of the Crime (1940). Before World War II Gould also worked as a social director for a venue in the Catskills, part of the "Borscht Belt."

Following the entry of the United States into World War II, Gould became a member of the Features Division in the Office of War Information for the U.S. Army in the North African Theater. He was deployed in 1943 as a non combatant in the Middle East and spent time in Palestine, Turkey, and Egypt, among other countries. Throughout his time in the army, he created reports on various war fronts and countries and wrote plays about the war, such as Homage to Bataan. He also created, wrote, and voiced the "Chaplain Jim" radio broadcast.

After World War II, Gould returned to writing, notably creating the Broadway show Tenting Tonight in 1947 (also referred to as Snow-Job in the collection), which was picked up by a number of theaters. At the same time, he began to write for magazines such as Reader's Digest, True Experience, and True Romance, assuming editorial reponsibility for both True Experience and True Romance. He also instructed aspiring playwrights at conferences around the country.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to all qualified researchers.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Taking images of documents from the library collections for referencec purposes by using hand-held cameras in accordance with the library's photography guidelines is encouraged. As an alternative, patrons may request up to 20 images per day from staff.

Application to use images from this collection for publication should be made in writing to: Department of Rights and Reproductions, The New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, New ork, NY 10024-5194, rightsandrepro@nyhitory.org. Phone: (212) 873-3400 ext. 282.

Copyrights and other proprietary rights may subsist in individuals and entities other than New-York Historical Society, in which case the patron is responsible for securing permission from those parties. For fuller information about rights and reproductions from N-YHS visit: www.nyhistory.org/about/rights-reproductions.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Nancy Gould Thompson and Rita Gould Maidat Sohni, daughters of Frank R. Gould, April 4, 2023.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Frank R. Gould Papers, MS 3228, New-York Historical Society.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Paul-Louis Biondi, N-YHS intern for the Princeton Internships in Civic Service, July 2023.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The New-York Historical Society Museum holds Gould's World War II blanket and knapsack.

Two of Gould's plays, The Scene of the Crime and Snow-Job, are housed in the Performing Arts Research Collection -- Theatre of the New York Public Library. Their call numbers are NCOF+ (Gould, F. Scene of the Crime) and RM 184, respectively.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Consisting of three boxes, this collection features complete original scripts, contracts, professional and personal correspondence, reviews of plays and radio dramas, short stories, newspaper and magazine articles, photographs, and military documents as well as a scrapbook made by Gould and a digital copy of his autobiography. The bulk of the materials document Gould's professional career on Broadway and in radio dramas as well as his subsequent work as a magazine editor for publications such as True Experience.

controlaccess.subject: Playwriting -- New York (State) -- New York.

controlaccess.corpname: United States. Office of War Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The material in this box documents some of the work Frank Gould did for the Office of War Information during World War II as a part of the Features Division in the Office of War Information. The documents, which include personal correspondence with Gould's wife (Ruth Yagendorf Gould), photographs, a script produced for the Office of War Information, and various documents from his time as a noncombatant employee, detail Gould's time in North Africa from 1943 to 1945.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Two letters to Ruth Yagendorf Gould, wife of Frank Gould, and one to his parents, written during his deployment.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photos from Gould's time abroad during World War II as well as a large-scale portrait of Frank Gould from later in his life.

did.unittitle: Play Script for the Office of War Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Homage to Bataan, written by Frank Gould for the Office of War Information.

did.unittitle: U.S. Army Administrative Documents and Papers

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Documents related to Frank Gould's deployment, including identification cards and press badges.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: German Phrase Book (1), Japanese Phrase Book (1), Italian Phrase Book (1).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Pair of U.S. Army cufflinks and rank insignia.

did.unittitle: Series II. Playwriting and Related Materials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box contains much of Gould's professional career, including original scripts for radio dramas and stage plays, contracts and letters from agents, and magazines for which he wrote or edited. The material ranges from 1931 to 1970.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes Radio Stars (March 1931), Advertising + Selling (June 6, 1935), CBS Program Book (November 1939), Story: The Magazine of the Short Story (Spring 1948, photocopy), and True Experience (April 1970).

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes a clipping about The Scene of the Crime, a program for The Ben Bard Players present "Tenting Tonight," a flyer about the American Repertory Theatre, a signed flyer from "Forty five years from Broadway in honor of the departing Steinhardts," a photograph of Gould sitting at a desk, and a typed list of Gould's writings divided into plays, radio and tv, and magazines.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes scripts for "Forgotten on November Twelfth" (November 12, 1935, presented by Fred Waring on The Ford Hour), "The Wonderful Day" (Columbia Workshop, November 30, 1939), "Main Street, U.S.A." (April 1940), Inner Sanctum Mysteries Script One (January 7, 1949), Inner Sanctum Mysteries No. 7 "The Strangled Snake" (February 18, 1941), Inner Sanctum Mysteries "The Patient Vanishes" (March 11, 1941), The Ave Maria Hour presents "The Story of Blessed Nuno Pereira" (November 5, 1950), The Ave Maria Hour presents "St. Camilius" (July 30, 1950). For scripts with both a recording date and a broadcast date, the broadcast date is given above.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes scripts for "Musical Fisticuffs," "Sound Over Matter," and three Bulldog Drummond scripts, one untitled script, "The Strange Death of Good Fairy," and "Murder with Gloves On."

did.unittitle: Tenting Tonight Licensing and Contractual Materials

odd.head: General
odd.p: Contracts, a certificate of copyright registration, correspondence regarding commissions, and box office statements for Tenting Tonight, also listed in the paperwork as Snow-Job.

odd.head: General
odd.p: Includes scripts for The Scene of the Crime (undated), Tenting Tonight (1946), and "The Adventures of Launcelot Butterflick Shmoolie, the Third" (undated).

odd.head: General
odd.p: Brochure for the Pacific Coast Writers Conference (1955), Bulletin no. 12 (Summer 1957) for Idyllwild Arts Foundation Writers Workshops and Conferences, and a letter from Idyllwild Writers Conference professor Frederick Shroyer about Frank Gould's contributions to the conference.

did.unittitle: Autobiography, God Shed His Grace on Me

odd.head: General
odd.p: Flash drive containing a copy of Gould's autobiography.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Created by Frank Gould, the scrapbook contains collages of reviews from Gould's shows, programs and tickets, pictures of Gould acting for radio dramas, and other documents. There are also some professional documents relating to Gould's projects.

did.unittitle: Series IV. Autobiography: God Shed His Grace on Me
